Visitors Defeat 'Varsity, 13 to 0—Black
and Blue Unable to Carry Ball.
Pepper and Kerr Stars
of Game.

Costly fumbles on the part of
Hopkins, together with theirinability to advance the ball, enabled George Washington to defeat the Black and Blue eleven at
Homewood on Saturday, 13 to 0.
With several new men in the
lineup, Hopkins had what might
be called a "hard luck" day, for
it chnnot be said that the visiting
eleven by any means was capable
of running the Black and Blue
team off their feet. On the other
hand, the teams were more or less
evenly matched. George Washington's victory was due to a
slightly superior backfield, to better teamwork and to the breaks
of the game, which almost without exception went against Hopkins,
The Black and Blue team
played by far a much better game
on the defensive than on the offensive. Time and again, with the
ball in Hopkins' territory the
Black and Blue line would hold
like iron and George Washington,
unable to advance the pigskin,
would be compelled to attempt a
drop-kick or a forward pass. On
the other hand, Hopkins, on the
offensive, at times could not gain
an inch. With the exception of a
few scattered end runs, the Black
and Blue team was hopeless when
it came to ground gaining.
..
George Washington had two
Players who contributed in a
large measure to Hopkins' defeat,
namely, Pepper, quarterback, and
Kerr, left tackle. Kerr nailed a
man on every play and when on the
defensive it usually was the man
with the ball. Pepper ran the visiting team with excellent judgment,
and himself made several substantial gains for his eleven. Branham) Woodward, Freedom and
Stanley starred for Hopkins.
Branham was about the only man
M the Hopkins backfield who
could cover ground, while Freedom, Stanley
and Woodward
Played the most consistent game
in the Hopkins
line.
George Washington scored a
touchdown in both the second and
third quarters. The first score
Came after a series of mishaps
for Hopkins. The ball was in
1.ocal territory and George Washington, unable to materially advance the ball, in quick succession
made three attempts at a
dropkick, but each attempt failed. The
first attempt came
in the first
quarter, after Hopkins had fum-

A LETTER FROM THE DEAN.

October 23, 1916.
To the Editor of The News-Letter:
Sir—Allow me to second
most sincerely your editorial
regarding the respect due the
Arms of the University in the
main entrance. If we do not
respect ourselves, who will respect us? Whenever we see the
coat of arms, let us remember
the motto on the earliest of our
national flags: "Don't Tread
On Me!" Yours very truly,

PRICE, FIVE CENTS.

TEAM MUST TAKE STRONG BRACE
Playing on Saturday Worst of Season.
Eleven Handicapped by Injuries
and Lack of Daylight
Practice.

By COACH BRENN1CK
Seldom has there been packed
within the four quarters of a .
game of football so much stupidity, supineness and listlessness as
was exhibited at Homewood on
Saturday.
Pitted against an
eleven that had no versatility of
attack, no speed—although, to be
sure, they did have physical
strength—our team seemed bent
on showing that they would not
be outdone in mediocrity. This
game was decidedly the worst
that our team has played thus
far and as it seems to the coaches
that
' the process of retrogression
has gone as far as it can go, it is
now hoped that a reversal in
form, may be brought about, so
that in the State championship
games, which are looming close
at hand, a respectable showing
may be made.
NO good can be accomplished
by making scathing criticisms of
individuals. The one outstanding
fact that confronts the team and
the coaches is that it is impossible under present conditions to
hold daylight scrimmage, with the
consequence that the very sort of
attack we should use, because of
the lightness- of our line, we are
precluded from using because we
cannot get the light necessary to
develop it.
The team Saturday was further
hand,icapped by the absence of
Captain Brooks, Uhler, Tippett
and Schmidt. There is no need
of my dwelling on this phase of
the game, for the student body
must know how different would
have been the situation had these
men been in the contest. The
coaches, at any rate, feel certain
that had Captain Brooks been in
the game, the floundering of the
backfield would not have been so
pronounced.
The line on defense played a
good game on the whole, but the
lack of weight is made most manifest on the attack, for it seems
that our forwards find it impossible to lift the opposing forwards
out of the path in order that the
backs may be able to get away.
This condition may be removed
next week, when some new men
from the Medical School are
scheduled to put in an appearance.
Out of the two defeats recently
sustained come some consoling
features one is that our men are
getting valuable experience, even
though at a great cost. In the

Menorah Society Holds Meeting.

The first meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Menorah Society was
held in the Donovan Room, Wednesday, October 25, at 1 o'clock.
Dr. Henry Slonimsky delivered a
lecture before the largest and most
enthusiastic audience that ever
attended a Menorah meeting.
The society has organized
three study circles, two in Modern
Hebrew, and one in Jewish history. It is hoped that these, together with the regular monthly
meetings, will make this year the
most successful in its history.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 30, 1916.

THE NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce that Franklin M. Earnest,
Jr., '19, has left the University,
and is therefore no longer a member of its editorial board. It also
wishes to announce that Arthur.
U. Hooper, '18, has been granted
leave of absence from the board
for one year.
Need for Systemization.

The conflict of dates was by no
means exceptional. Time and
again, as every student activity
will bear witness, such conflicts
have occurred, and there have been
either poorly attended meetings,
or disheartening and entirely unnecessary postponements. None
of our organizations is so free of
problems of its own which it must
work out that it can afford to add
another handicap to its list, especially when such a handicap, by
the use of a little foresight, can be
easily eliminated.
The solution is simple. Let no
organization have the right to call
a meeting without the sanction of
the Student Council; when the
time for a meeting has been fixed,
save in exceptional circumstances,
let no other meeting be called for
that hour. Then let the schedule
for the week be prominently
posted on a bulletin board reserved for that especial purpose.
There need be no red tape involved in such a scheme. The Student Council need not convene to
consider every petition; two or
three of its members can form a
permanent committee commissioned with power to consider all
applications. In general, it may
safely be said that every organization can plan its meeting a week
in advance. There may, of course,
be cases where two meetings are so
obviously devoid of any possibility
of conflict that they can be held
at the same time with perfect harmony, or cases where unusual circumstances warrant an overriding
of pre-arranged schedules. Such
cases could be left to the discretion of the committee; there need
be no hard and fast rule—only a
co-ordination, the machinery for
which is already in existence, and
which, in operation, would save a
great deal of confusion. THE
NEWS-LETTER respectfully submits
the plan to the Student Council
for consideration.

Adams Literary Society, and the
Glee Club—were scheduled to

three meetings were important,
and there were many men who desired to be present at each. Nor

should see the logical time for the
beginning of its work.
For three successive years, Hopkins has won the annual triangular debate between this University and the Universities of North
Carolina and Virginia. That is a
record of which any institution
might be proud, and it is a record
which must be maintained. A
North Carolina exchange recently
carried the announcement that a
freshman debating society of 50
men had been formed—these men,
of course, it went on, not being
eligible for either of the two university societies. If Hopkins
wishes to continue its unbroken
line of victories, it must develop
its literary material; and for such
development, the Adams offers opportunity.
Yet the Adams will by no means
serve only as a subsidiary organization. It will have debates of its
own, both among its own members, and with the societies of
other universities, and it will
bring a community of interest to
men for whom that community
has always been a need distinctly
felt. There is no institution of
Hopkins' size or reputation in the
country which has not a literary
society among its most fixed institutions.
The Adams should be supported
by men from every class, but to
freshmen and sophomores particularly it offers unusual advantages.
The men from these classes have
not the training ground offered
by the Senior-Junior debate; in
the past, their literary material
has had comparatively no chance
of expansion. The Adams fulfills
that want; it asks for support
from every student, and to every
student it affords the same opportunities.

The recent graduation of two
Japanese women from the University of Sandal, Japan, with the
degree of rikakushi, or bachelor
of science, marks an epoch in the
advance of education in Japan.
The Imperial University w a s
opened to women four years ago.
—Ex.
* * *
An assessment of $57 is levied
on each senior at the University
of California for the purpose of
raising a memorial trust fund of
$50,000.—Ex.
* *
Fire, fanned by a high wind,
virtually destroyed the main
building of the University of Wisconsin on October 10. Five hundred students, warned by a fire
alarm system installed just two
months ago, marched out of the
building in safety and assisted in
saving the old records of the institution.—Ex.
George Washington University
will meet the University of North
Carolina in the second annual debate with that institution on or
•about December 15.—Ex.
* • •
The largest university band in
the United States is at the University of Illinois. Over 200
pieces were present at the university's twenty-sixth annual concert.
—Ex.
Beginning next semester, the
Missouri School of Mines will discontinue final examinations.—Ex.
According to a recent investigation of the Intercollegiate Prohibition Association- over a hundred colleges are now offering curriculum courses in the study of
the liquor problem.—Ex.
* • *
The University of Nevada has
recently installed a night,school
for law students.—Ex.

Monument Street Building for Its
Contests—Independent Hopkins

BRANHAM, HALFBACK
Photograph by J Stocksolale.

Y. M. C. A. RECEIVES REQUEST
FOR SOCIAL SERVICE WORKERS

The West Park Recreation Centre recently made a definite request to the Hopkins Y. M. C. A.
that 15 or 20 students, who are interested in social service work,
might be sent to that recreation
centre to help in the work there.
Any students who would be interested in work of this sort
should see P. B. Strobel or A. K.
Chalmers, who can give them full
particulars.
Chapel services were led for the
past week by Dean Murray P.
Brush. The Dean gave a brief
outline of the way in which college students should employ their
time in order to get the most good
out of their collegiate life. Prof.
C. J. Tilden, of the Engineering
School, is leader this week, and
large attendances are desired.
Everyone is welcome.
As alinounced in THE NEWS-LETTER last week, Allan K. Chalmers
had been removed from the position of vice-president of the association to that of assistant general secretary. His successor as
vice-presideht will be elected early
this week.
She—Did you hear the chimney
swallow?
Embarrassed Youth — That
wasn't the chimney, Ethel, that
was I.—Harvard Lampoon.

The Interclass Basket - ball
League, which met with much
success last year, will be formed
again this year. At first it was
thought that it could not be organized at Homewood as there
seemed to be no place to stage
the games. But lately two places
for the contests have presented
themselves. They are the old
gymnasium down on Howard
street and the old Gilman gymnasium.
All of the apparatus will be
taken out of the old gymnasium
and will be brought out to Homewood, leaving the floor absolutely
clear. An effort will be made to
secure this building, but if this
fails the games will in all probability be staged in the building at
Homewood. At present, this floor
is not in use and the hopes of the
men interested in the league seem
to have an excellent chance of being realized.
Both the senior and sophomore
teams, which, as juniors and freshmen, put up such a strong fight
for the leadership in the league,
are practically intact this year—
the only man lost by either team
being Frock, center on last year's
freshman team—and another excellent battle for the supremacy
of the league is expected. The
last year's sophomore team was
by no means bad and may cause
considerable anxiety in this year's
league. The sophomore team was
made up of men capable of playing an excellent game of basketball, but they did not seem able
to work together. In only two or
three of the games were they playing up to their true form and if
they get a good start this year
they will bear watching.
If enough interest is taken in
the game, an independent University team will be chosen to
play the other college teams in
Maryland and in this vicinity.
Should a University team be
chosen, it would undoubtedly be
successful, with such men as
Brooks and Cox for the guards
and P. Sutton, Love and Pfitsch
for forwards.
A contract has been signed between the athletic authorities of
Georgia Tech and Auburn which
insures a gridiron battle between
these two institutions in Atlanta
on Thanksgiving Day for five
years. The contract takes effect
with the season of 1916 and lasts
through the season of 1920.—Ex.

A Discussion of the Football Situation.

October 26, 1916.
To the Editor of Tnt NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—Your editorial in the last
issue was a fluent and artistic attempt to explain what you term
"a serious situation," namely: t4e
spirit, or rather the lack of spirit,
exhibited in support of our football team. The facts, as you
stated them, are sad and undeniable. Hopkins does lack spirit.
You grew eloquent over this; then
you placed part of the blame upon
"six or eight men whose presence
would strengthen the team a hundred per cent." Overlooking this
slight exaggeration, I found you
to be vague in pointing to the real
cause; and furthermore, you offered no logical remedy. You
know that it is impossible to talk
a man into "spirit." That must
come of its own accord. You say
that."Hopkins has not awakened;
the spirit which carried our eleven
through to the winning of the
state championship last year has
been lost." You do not penetrate
far enough. You say, "the active
support which the student body
has given its team has been so
slight, so casual, so utterly dispirited, that it has been worse
than negligible. No cheering at
all would have been preferable to
the cheering which has characterized the last three games. Some
men do not come out to the
games; others do not sit in the
cheering section; others sit in the
Cheering section and are under
the impression that the mere act
of sitting there fulfills every obligation which could ever rest
Upon them."
In other words, the student
body is utterly disinterested. And
it will take more than your words,
or mine, to arouse us.
The fault does not lie with us.
It lies with the Athletic Association. Our Athletic Association
management is the most inefficient, narrow-minded and blameworthy institution in the University at present. In every branch
of athletics, but most particularly
in football, are we hindered by its
languid inertia. Its members
seem to believe that its sole purpose is to make money. The football clothes which these financiers
Preserve from year to year. have
undoubtedly witnessed football in
its infancy. The headguards also
seem to be remnants of the

against men who at least will be
no heavier than our recent opponents. The other fact is that in
these last two games we have been
far from having our strongest
lineup on the field, because of the
long list of minor injuries which
has beset the squad this fall.
Nevertheless, this loss of time is
a loss and the coaches will have
to work to their utmost to organize
the team so as to get the most
out of the material. There is
nothing miraculous about the
game of football, despite the talk
of "miracle men." To make a
team we must have material and
the time to work it into shape.
If ever the team and the coaches
needed the backing of the University, it is now. The team is dispirited and the coaches are far
from proud of their own work
this season. All of us ask your
co-operation and support. We
are neither despondent nor hopeless, but we do feel that if we are
to whip Western Maryland, beat
St. John's and emulate the 1915
team when we meet Maryland
State, then we must set about our
task now. What a great season
it would be if the University
would rise in its might and show
that its student body could face
a stiff crisis and emerge, if not
victorious, at any rate glorified!

The line in our ancient Alma
Mater ode, "The Hopkins men on
the football field have won a great
renown" sounds flat. I imagine
the aforesaid Harvard man saying, "I won't be out Saturday;
I'm going to take Mary Ann to
the theater."
Your statement
that "for the majority of Hopkins men, the State championship, compared to their lunch,
seems to be entirely a minor matter" hits the point.
In conclusion, I wish to reiterate that the blame rests entirely on ,he Athletic Association.
For years they have done no constructive work for the athletics
of the University. We, at Hopkins, are for the most part normal beings. Let them develop
undergraduate teams and this
will arouse spirit of itself. Give
its something over which to enthuse and we will respond only
too gladly. Cut out graduates,
train freshmen, make eligibility
rules. I admit that this will
mean poor teams for several
years—yet. But let us try. We
are bound to emerge from such

a rennaissance, having developed
that vestige of spirit which we
now have.
Can you suggest a better plan?
Or shall we continue in our present inert condition—winning (or
possibly losing) State championships.

A LETTER FROM THE DEAN.

October 23, 1916.
To the Editor of The News-Letter:
Sir—Allow me to second
most sincerely your editorial
regarding the respect due the
Arms of the University in the
main entrance. If we do not
respect ourselves, who will respect us? Whenever we see the
coat of arms, let us remember
the motto on the earliest of our
national flags: "Don't Tread
On Me!" Yours very truly,

PRICE, FIVE CENTS.

TEAM MUST TAKE STRONG BRACE
Playing on Saturday Worst of Season.
Eleven Handicapped by Injuries
and Lack of Daylight
Practice.

By COACH BRENN1CK
Seldom has there been packed
within the four quarters of a .
game of football so much stupidity, supineness and listlessness as
was exhibited at Homewood on
Saturday.
Pitted against an
eleven that had no versatility of
attack, no speed—although, to be
sure, they did have physical
strength—our team seemed bent
on showing that they would not
be outdone in mediocrity. This
game was decidedly the worst
that our team has played thus
far and as it seems to the coaches
that
' the process of retrogression
has gone as far as it can go, it is
now hoped that a reversal in
form, may be brought about, so
that in the State championship
games, which are looming close
at hand, a respectable showing
may be made.
NO good can be accomplished
by making scathing criticisms of
individuals. The one outstanding
fact that confronts the team and
the coaches is that it is impossible under present conditions to
hold daylight scrimmage, with the
consequence that the very sort of
attack we should use, because of
the lightness- of our line, we are
precluded from using because we
cannot get the light necessary to
develop it.
The team Saturday was further
hand,icapped by the absence of
Captain Brooks, Uhler, Tippett
and Schmidt. There is no need
of my dwelling on this phase of
the game, for the student body
must know how different would
have been the situation had these
men been in the contest. The
coaches, at any rate, feel certain
that had Captain Brooks been in
the game, the floundering of the
backfield would not have been so
pronounced.
The line on defense played a
good game on the whole, but the
lack of weight is made most manifest on the attack, for it seems
that our forwards find it impossible to lift the opposing forwards
out of the path in order that the
backs may be able to get away.
This condition may be removed
next week, when some new men
from the Medical School are
scheduled to put in an appearance.
Out of the two defeats recently
sustained come some consoling
features one is that our men are
getting valuable experience, even
though at a great cost. In the

Menorah Society Holds Meeting.

The first meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Menorah Society was
held in the Donovan Room, Wednesday, October 25, at 1 o'clock.
Dr. Henry Slonimsky delivered a
lecture before the largest and most
enthusiastic audience that ever
attended a Menorah meeting.
The society has organized
three study circles, two in Modern
Hebrew, and one in Jewish history. It is hoped that these, together with the regular monthly
meetings, will make this year the
most successful in its history.

THE NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce that Franklin M. Earnest,
Jr., '19, has left the University,

Need for Systemization.

The conflict of dates was by no
means exceptional. Time and
again, as every student activity
will bear witness, such conflicts
have occurred, and there have been
either poorly attended meetings,
or disheartening and entirely unnecessary postponements. None
of our organizations is so free of
problems of its own which it must
work out that it can afford to add
another handicap to its list, especially when such a handicap, by
the use of a little foresight, can be
easily eliminated.
The solution is simple. Let no
organization have the right to call
a meeting without the sanction of
the Student Council; when the
time for a meeting has been fixed,
save in exceptional circumstances,
let no other meeting be called for
that hour. Then let the schedule
for the week be prominently
posted on a bulletin board reserved for that especial purpose.
There need be no red tape involved in such a scheme. The Student Council need not convene to
consider every petition; two or
three of its members can form a
permanent committee commissioned with power to consider all
applications. In general, it may
safely be said that every organization can plan its meeting a week
in advance. There may, of course,
be cases where two meetings are so
obviously devoid of any possibility
of conflict that they can be held
at the same time with perfect harmony, or cases where unusual circumstances warrant an overriding
of pre-arranged schedules. Such
cases could be left to the discretion of the committee; there need
be no hard and fast rule—only a
co-ordination, the machinery for
which is already in existence, and
which, in operation, would save a
great deal of confusion. THE
NEWS-LETTER respectfully submits
the plan to the Student Council
for consideration.

For three successive years, Hopkins has won the annual triangular debate between this University and the Universities of North
Carolina and Virginia. That is a
record of which any institution
might be proud, and it is a record
which must be maintained. A
North Carolina exchange recently
carried the announcement that a
freshman debating society of 50
men had been formed—these men,
of course, it went on, not being
eligible for either of the two university societies. If Hopkins
wishes to continue its unbroken
line of victories, it must develop
its literary material; and for such
development, the Adams offers opportunity.
Yet the Adams will by no means
serve only as a subsidiary organization. It will have debates of its
own, both among its own members, and with the societies of
other universities, and it will
bring a community of interest to
men for whom that community
has always been a need distinctly
felt. There is no institution of
Hopkins' size or reputation in the
country which has not a literary
society among its most fixed institutions.
The Adams should be supported
by men from every class, but to
freshmen and sophomores particularly it offers unusual advantages.
The men from these classes have
not the training ground offered
by the Senior-Junior debate; in
the past, their literary material
has had comparatively no chance
of expansion. The Adams fulfills
that want; it asks for support
from every student, and to every
student it affords the same opportunities.

The recent graduation of two
Japanese women from the University of Sandal, Japan, with the
degree of rikakushi, or bachelor
of science, marks an epoch in the
advance of education in Japan.
The Imperial University w a s
opened to women four years ago.

of California for the purpose of
raising a memorial trust fund of

Fire, fanned by a high wind,
virtually destroyed the main
building of the University of Wisconsin on October 10. Five hundred students, warned by a fire
alarm system installed just two
months ago, marched out of the
building in safety and assisted in
saving the old records of the institution.—Ex.

will meet the University of North
Carolina in the second annual debate with that institution on or

Basket-ball League May Go Back to
Monument Street Building for Its
Contests—Independent Hopkins

BRANHAM, HALFBACK
Photograph by J Stocksolale.

Y. M. C. A. RECEIVES REQUEST
FOR SOCIAL SERVICE WORKERS

The West Park Recreation Centre recently made a definite request to the Hopkins Y. M. C. A.
that 15 or 20 students, who are interested in social service work,
might be sent to that recreation
centre to help in the work there.
Any students who would be interested in work of this sort
should see P. B. Strobel or A. K.
Chalmers, who can give them full
particulars.
Chapel services were led for the
past week by Dean Murray P.
Brush. The Dean gave a brief
outline of the way in which college students should employ their
time in order to get the most good
out of their collegiate life. Prof.
C. J. Tilden, of the Engineering
School, is leader this week, and
large attendances are desired.
Everyone is welcome.
As alinounced in THE NEWS-LETTER last week, Allan K. Chalmers
had been removed from the position of vice-president of the association to that of assistant general secretary. His successor as
vice-presideht will be elected early
this week.
She—Did you hear the chimney
swallow?
Embarrassed Youth — That
wasn't the chimney, Ethel, that
was I.—Harvard Lampoon.

The Interclass Basket - ball
League, which met with much
success last year, will be formed
again this year. At first it was
thought that it could not be organized at Homewood as there
seemed to be no place to stage
the games. But lately two places
for the contests have presented
themselves. They are the old
gymnasium down on Howard
street and the old Gilman gymnasium.
All of the apparatus will be
taken out of the old gymnasium
and will be brought out to Homewood, leaving the floor absolutely
clear. An effort will be made to
secure this building, but if this
fails the games will in all probability be staged in the building at
Homewood. At present, this floor
is not in use and the hopes of the
men interested in the league seem
to have an excellent chance of being realized.
Both the senior and sophomore
teams, which, as juniors and freshmen, put up such a strong fight
for the leadership in the league,
are practically intact this year—
the only man lost by either team
being Frock, center on last year's
freshman team—and another excellent battle for the supremacy
of the league is expected. The
last year's sophomore team was
by no means bad and may cause
considerable anxiety in this year's
league. The sophomore team was
made up of men capable of playing an excellent game of basketball, but they did not seem able
to work together. In only two or
three of the games were they playing up to their true form and if
they get a good start this year
they will bear watching.
If enough interest is taken in
the game, an independent University team will be chosen to
play the other college teams in
Maryland and in this vicinity.
Should a University team be
chosen, it would undoubtedly be
successful, with such men as
Brooks and Cox for the guards
and P. Sutton, Love and Pfitsch
for forwards.
A contract has been signed between the athletic authorities of
Georgia Tech and Auburn which
insures a gridiron battle between
these two institutions in Atlanta
on Thanksgiving Day for five
years. The contract takes effect
with the season of 1916 and lasts
through the season of 1920.—Ex.

A Discussion of the Football Situation.

October 26, 1916.
To the Editor of Tnt NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—Your editorial in the last
issue was a fluent and artistic attempt to explain what you term
"a serious situation," namely: t4e
spirit, or rather the lack of spirit,
exhibited in support of our football team. The facts, as you
stated them, are sad and undeniable. Hopkins does lack spirit.
You grew eloquent over this; then
you placed part of the blame upon
"six or eight men whose presence
would strengthen the team a hundred per cent." Overlooking this
slight exaggeration, I found you
to be vague in pointing to the real
cause; and furthermore, you offered no logical remedy. You
know that it is impossible to talk
a man into "spirit." That must
come of its own accord. You say
that."Hopkins has not awakened;
the spirit which carried our eleven
through to the winning of the
state championship last year has
been lost." You do not penetrate
far enough. You say, "the active
support which the student body
has given its team has been so
slight, so casual, so utterly dispirited, that it has been worse
than negligible. No cheering at
all would have been preferable to
the cheering which has characterized the last three games. Some
men do not come out to the
games; others do not sit in the
cheering section; others sit in the
Cheering section and are under
the impression that the mere act
of sitting there fulfills every obligation which could ever rest
Upon them."
In other words, the student
body is utterly disinterested. And
it will take more than your words,
or mine, to arouse us.
The fault does not lie with us.
It lies with the Athletic Association. Our Athletic Association
management is the most inefficient, narrow-minded and blameworthy institution in the University at present. In every branch
of athletics, but most particularly
in football, are we hindered by its
languid inertia. Its members
seem to believe that its sole purpose is to make money. The football clothes which these financiers

undoubtedly witnessed football in
its infancy. The headguards also

The line in our ancient Alma
Mater ode, "The Hopkins men on
the football field have won a great
renown" sounds flat. I imagine
the aforesaid Harvard man saying, "I won't be out Saturday;
I'm going to take Mary Ann to
the theater."
Your statement
that "for the majority of Hopkins men, the State championship, compared to their lunch,
seems to be entirely a minor matter" hits the point.
In conclusion, I wish to reiterate that the blame rests entirely on ,he Athletic Association.
For years they have done no constructive work for the athletics
of the University. We, at Hopkins, are for the most part normal beings. Let them develop
undergraduate teams and this
will arouse spirit of itself. Give
its something over which to enthuse and we will respond only
too gladly. Cut out graduates,
train freshmen, make eligibility
rules. I admit that this will
mean poor teams for several
years—yet. But let us try. We
are bound to emerge from such

a rennaissance, having developed
that vestige of spirit which we
now have.
Can you suggest a better plan?
Or shall we continue in our present inert condition—winning (or
possibly losing) State championships.
A WOULD-BE ROOTER.
